title: Suppose that someone writes an email to his friend Julia. Is it rude to write her name with a lowercase 'j'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are they using caps elsewhere? Is their caps key broken? Does Julia have a problem with it? Does she use caps in their usual positions when she writes emails to this friend? Does the friend get irritated if someone writes their own name without the caps? In my case I prefer gud spelin wh’nevah posibol, whether it is in an email, IM or whatever, simply because it’s easier to read; I don’t need to be deciphering “what was this person trying to say” word by word. And “people writing my name wrong when they’re answering to an email that’s got it spelled correctly” is beyond a pet peeve: sometimes it’s an honest mistake (these apologize when I point it out and avoid doing it again), but for some it’s a power play and yes, disrespectful. People who tell me it’s “no fucking deal” always turn out to get angry when others misspell their names. If Julia likes her name with a cap J, then that’s how it should be written. Because it’s HER name, not yours or mine. If she liked it written julIa I’d think it’s a bit silly, but I’d write it julIa: because it’s HER name.

Consistency is polite. If the the entire email (including other names) is in lower case, then you’re not singling julia out in any way. Perfectly courteous, no problem. However, when you capitalize Percival and Melisande and Cyril but poor julia stays lowercase, that’s putting her down, which is rude. See what I did there? “Putting her down” because you’re using lower case not upper case. Ha hee hee hoo ha snort. Grammar puns are hilarious.
